field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The COVID-19 situation in Tanzania, as of May 2025, shows a concerning upward trend, with Dar es Salaam identified as the most affected region. While no other new regions are specifically mentioned, the overall increase in reported cases suggests a nationwide rise in transmission. The report does not specify affected population groups based on age or vulnerability, but it highlights a general increase in community-level infections, indicating that all citizens are at potential risk and should remain vigilant.

From February to April 2025, infection rates rose significantlyâ€”from 1.4% in February (2 out of 139 tested) to 16.3% in March (31 out of 190 tested), and 16.8% in April (31 out of 185 tested). This steady increase confirms a worsening trend in the spread of the virus. In response, the Ministry of Health has intensified disease surveillance and testing efforts at health centers. Citizens are strongly advised to seek immediate medical care if they experience symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, fatigue, muscle pain, or breathing difficulties.
field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 05-2025 - COVID-19 TREND IN TANZANIA
field_reports.description:
The primary effect of the rising COVID-19 cases in Tanzania, particularly in Dar es Salaam, is an increased burden on the health system, which is now facing heightened pressure due to the sharp rise in infections from February to April 2025. Health facilities are required to ramp up surveillance, testing, and treatment, stretching both human and material resources. The Ministry of Health has deployed more diagnostic capacity to detect COVID-19 and other viral illnesses such as influenza, as mentioned in the public health alert issued on 20 May 2025. The rise in infections also threatens to divert resources from ongoing responses to other public health threats, such as mosquito-borne diseases (e.g., dengue and malaria), which are exacerbated by the ongoing rainy season.

The secondary effects are being felt at the community level, where the increase in COVID-19 cases is causing disruption to daily life, economic hardship, and psychosocial stress among the affected population. Although the report does not provide disaggregated data, the trend suggests that entire communities are at risk, with the potential for further spread if preventive measures are not adhered to. There is also an increased risk of misinformation and fear, particularly as the symptoms of COVID-19 overlap with other common illnesses, making early identification challenging. Public health messaging, therefore, is crucial to ensure that citizens understand the importance of timely testing and treatment, as well as the continued use of preventive measures like mask-wearing, hand hygiene, and physical distancing.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 05-2025 - KYELA FLOODS IN MBEYA REGION TANZANIA
field_reports.description:
Date: 15th May 2025
Location: Kyela, Rungwe, and Ileje Districts – Mbeya and Songwe Regions, Southern Highlands, Tanzania

From 14th to 15th May 2025, heavy and continuous rainfall caused widespread flooding in the southern highlands of Tanzania, particularly affecting Kyela, Rungwe, and Ileje districts. In Kyela District, excess runoff from the highlands overflowed into Lake Nyasa, inundating 15 villages across 5 wards. The wards most affected and currently hosting displaced populations in evacuation centers include Katumba Songwe, Mwaya, Kajunjumele, and Ipinda. A total of over 452 households (approx. 3,150 individuals) have been displaced and are currently sheltered in 4 evacuation sites, including schools and temporary shelters. No deaths have been reported in this incident, though five individuals are missing and 21 have sustained injuries. Access to basic services like food, clean water, and sanitation in these shelters remains critically limited.

The floods have caused extensive damage to homes, infrastructure, and farmland. 318 houses were completely destroyed, while 436 were partially damaged. Vital infrastructure such as five water wells have been contaminated, four bridges and three major roads were swept away, and communication networks in several areas remain disrupted. Social services have also been hit hard, with 35 schools, 12 churches, and 4 mosques damaged. Agricultural losses are severe, with thousands of hectares of crops including maize, rice, vegetables, bananas, cocoa, and cassava destroyed, posing a serious threat to food security and livelihoods in the affected communities.

In response, the Tanzania Red Cross Society (TRCS) in collaboration with Kyela District Authorities conducted a rapid assessment to determine urgent needs. TRCS has been actively engaged in providing emergency health services, psychological first aid, evacuation and rescue support, and camp management at shelters. The Government of Tanzania has also stepped in by establishing four emergency shelters currently hosting over 100 households, and is supplying food assistance to those in the camps. However, the government continues to request further support from TRCS and other Disaster Management Committee members to meet the growing humanitarian needs. The IFRC Juba Cluster is providing technical support to TRCS for coordination and resource mobilization, although the current DREF operation is focused on Mara and Morogoro regions.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 03-2025 - High rainfall and strong wind
field_reports.description:
Between March 21-24, 2025, heavy rainfall and strong winds severely impacted Musoma (Mara Region) and Ulanga (Morogoro Region), causing widespread destruction, displacement, and urgent humanitarian needs.

In Musoma, storms damaged 524 households, destroying 165 houses and leaving 65 people in temporary shelters. Critical infrastructure, including sewage systems, power, and water supply, was severely affected, with contaminated water sources increasing the risk of a cholera outbreak.

In Ulanga, 433 houses collapsed, displacing 2,165 people who are now in evacuation centers or seeking refuge with relatives. Families lost food stocks, household items, and crops, worsening food insecurity. The situation remains critical as rainfall continues, increasing the risk of further damage.

Emergency response efforts, including food distribution, shelter support, and psychosocial assistance, are ongoing. However, urgent humanitarian support is needed, including food, shelter, water treatment supplies, and healthcare services, to assist affected communities.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 02-2025 - Mtwara Floods In Tanzania
field_reports.description:
Background

Heavy rains have caused severe flooding across Mtwara Region, leading to widespread destruction and displacement. The floods have significantly impacted infrastructure, homes, and livelihoods, leaving many families in urgent need of assistance.

Impact and Humanitarian Needs

  • Housing Damage:
    • 195 houses have completely collapsed.
    • 746 houses have been fully submerged in floodwaters.
  • Displacement: Hundreds of families have been forced to evacuate, seeking shelter in temporary camps or with relatives.
  • Infrastructure Damage: Roads and bridges have been damaged, limiting access to affected communities and making relief efforts challenging.
  • Health Risks: The risk of waterborne diseases such as cholera and malaria has increased due to stagnant water and lack of sanitation.
  • Livelihood Disruption: Flooded farmlands threaten food security, impacting both subsistence farmers and market supply chains.
  • Immediate Needs: Urgent humanitarian assistance is required, including emergency shelter, food, clean water, and medical support.

Response Efforts

  • Tanzania Red Cross Society (TRCS) and local authorities are working to provide relief assistance to displaced families.
  • Emergency shelters are being set up for those who have lost their homes.
  • Health and hygiene promotion efforts are being intensified to prevent disease outbreaks.
  • WASH interventions are being prioritized, including distribution of water purification tablets and hygiene kits.

Next Steps

  • Ongoing assessments to determine additional needs and long-term recovery plans.
  • Expansion of cash assistance programs to help affected households rebuild their lives.
  • Coordination with humanitarian partners to ensure a sustainable response and disaster preparedness measures.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 01-2025 - Unidentified Epidemic Outbreak in Kagera, Tanzania
field_reports.description:
On January 9, 2025, the Regional Emergency Operations Center (EOC) in Kagera Region reported an outbreak of an unknown illness originating in Biharamulo District. To date, nine cases have been identified, resulting in eight fatalities (Case Fatality Rate: 88.9%). The illness is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, headache, back pain, diarrhea, vomiting blood, and bleeding from open areas at advanced stages.

Key Details:
Index Case: A 27-year-old pregnant woman from Chankende Hamlet in Katerera village, who succumbed after a miscarriage.
Transmission Chain: The disease has affected close family members, traditional healers, healthcare workers, and others who came into contact with the deceased.
Geographical Spread: Cases are concentrated in Biharamulo District, with recent suspected deaths reported in Muleba.
Current Cases: One patient remains in isolation at Biharamulo District Hospital and is reportedly stable. Two additional deaths were reported in Muleba following a burial event linked to the outbreak.

The illness is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, headache, back pain, diarrhea, vomiting blood, and bleeding from open areas at advanced stages. field_reports.summary: TZA: Landslide - 12-2024 - Ngorongoro Landslide in Tanzania
field_reports.description: A Landslide Warning has been indicated by the Landslide Hazard Assessment Model (LHASA) on December 4, 2024, 12:41:00 UTC for Eastern Rift Mountains, Ngorongoro, Arusha, Tanzania. Landslide Warnings indicate a significant risk of rainfall induced landslide. It is estimated that 22,300 people, 4,590 households, and $2.24 Million of infrastructure* are within the affected area(s). *The cost represents the total replacement value of the infrastructure. Affected areas include: Arusha

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 11-2024 - TANZANIA TARIME FLOODS
field_reports.description:
Tragic news from Tarime District in the Mara Region of Tanzania confirms that nine members of one family have drowned following heavy rains that caused severe flooding. The floods swept away their home, along with three other houses, leaving several families homeless.

Acting Regional Fire and Rescue Commander Augustine Magere stated that unplanned construction near the river contributed significantly to the tragedy, as the affected houses were located close to the waterway.

This incident highlights the dangers of building in flood-prone areas and underscores the importance of following construction regulations to minimize the risks associated with natural disasters. Authorities are urging residents to prioritize safety and adhere to official guidance in such vulnerable locations.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Other - 11-2024 - Urgent Response to Kariakoo Building Collapse: Lives Lost and Rescues Ongoing
field_reports.description:
Situational Overview: Kariakoo Building Collapse in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania

Date and Location: On November 16, 2024, a multi-story building in the Kariakoo district of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, unexpectedly collapsed. Kariakoo is a bustling commercial area, making this incident particularly devastating due to its dense population and high activity.

Impact:

  • Casualties: At least 13 people have been confirmed dead.
  • Injuries: Over 84 individuals have sustained injuries, ranging from minor to critical.
  • Rescued: Emergency teams have rescued more than 84 individuals from the rubble, with efforts ongoing to locate any remaining survivorsâ€‹
     
    â€‹
     

Actions Taken:

  • Tanzania Red Cross:
    • Provided immediate first aid and psychosocial support to survivors and families.
    • Assisted in search-and-rescue operations, supplying oxygen, water, and other essentials to trapped victims.
    • Supported local hospitals with medical assistance for the injured.
    • provided pyscho social services and mental health services to the affected families and individuals 
  • Government Efforts:
    • President Samia Suluhu Hassan has ordered a comprehensive inspection of buildings in Kariakoo to prevent similar incidents.
    • Authorities are providing free medical care for victims and assistance with burial arrangements for the deceasedâ€‹
       
      â€‹
       
      Current Challenges:
  • The risk of further collapse in adjacent buildings poses a safety concern for responders.
  • Heavy machinery is being deployed to speed up rescue operations, though debris clearance remains a complex task.
  • Families of the victims are in urgent need of psychological and material support.

Urgent Needs:

  • Continued support for search-and-rescue operations.
  • Medical aid for the injured.
  • Shelter and psychosocial assistance for affected families.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Other - 08-2024 - Epidemic 2024-08 Tanzania-Anticipatory Actions Monkey Pox  Outbreak
field_reports.description: The Monkey pox outbreak was reported in Kenya on 31th July  2024 at the Taita Taveta one stop border from an individual travelling from Uganda to Rwanda though Kenya which is 127.7 km from the Tanzanian boarder, putting Tanzania at risk of cross-border transmission. The two countries share many points of entry, with people conducting economic activities without any movement restrictions. TRCS has mapped 4 regions at risk, 5 directly bordering Kenya, (Kilimanjaro, Arusha, Tanga, and Mara). with total population of 9,205,801

The two countries share many points of entry, with people conducting economic activities without any movement restrictions. TRCS has mapped 4 regions at risk, 5 directly bordering Kenya, (Kilimanjaro, Arusha, Tanga, and Mara). with total population of 9,205,801

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 07-2024 - TANZANIA CHOLERA OUTBREAK
field_reports.description: In Tanzania from last year in September 2023, there has been a lot of heavy rain which has caused an outbreak of cholera in many regions of Tanzania, in February 2024 Tanzania Red Cross requested IFRC DREF to support intervention in three regions Mwanza, Kagera and Shinyanga and succeeded to help the government and stakeholders to eradicate Cholera  in the regions mentioned above, starting from 12th July 2024 TRCS through Volunteers present in Hanang at Appleal and doing case management, and PSS managed to report the existence of this Cholera disease, TRCS HQ through the disaster department was able to communication with the Ministry of Health and to be able to get reliable information to be able to see which important area can get help very quickly, TRCS has sent Volunteers to the areas that have experienced challenges and to be able to sign with the government to manage two camps established in Manyara region to deal with this disease so far 3 people have been reported dead

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 01-2024 - TANZANIA CHOLERA OUTBREAK
field_reports.description: In early January 2024, cholera epidemics struck several regions in Tanzania. The situation was caused by Continuous of heavy rainfall due to effect of El nino season ,downpours, poor access to potable water and lack of sanitation facilities and community awareness. Initial assessment carried by the National Society (NS) disaster management and health department revealed that Mwanza, Simiyu, Kagera, Ruvuma, Geita, and Tabora region hav e been affected and with cholera and our Volunteer continue with initial assessment, case management and surveillance collaborated with Regional medical officers. The Ministry of Health ,Surveillance Service and emergency operation center confirmed the outbreak on 05 January. As of 8th December, 2024 the total number of cases was 816 with 26 deaths recorded in 6 out of 31 regions. These figures confirmed that the disease was rapidly spreading and immediate action needed to be taken.

results.summary:
Since September 5th, 2023, a cholera outbreak has been reported in 13 regions of Mara, Arusha, Kilimanjaro, Kigoma, Kagera, Singida, Simiyu, Shinyanga, Tabora, Ruvuma, Dodoma, Mwanza, and Geita in Tanzania Mainland, with cumulatively 1,521 cases and 34 deaths (CFR of 2.3%) reported. Out of 13 regions, a Cholera outbreak was declared over in 5 regions (Mara, Kigoma, Arusha, Kilimanjaro, and Dodoma). Cases in Mwanza, Shinyanga, Simiyu and Kagera regions have continued to increase to date, making these regions the most affected at present. The trend of this disease shows that there is a risk of the disease spreading further, if necessary, measures are not put in place. With the ongoing El nino a long rains period expected to start in March through May 2024, there is a probability that these cases will rise, and more regions will be affected.Â 

Tanzania has never experienced an almost countrywide spread of cholera infections in the last 4 decades. At most, it has only been witnessed and quickly contained in up to two regions concurrently per year. With the present El Nino rains in all 31 administrative regions of Tanzania, the existing wastewater drainage systems have been overwhelmed and many have collapsed completely, particularly those of Mwanza, Shinyanga and Kagera. The regions also happen to be the most densely populated in the country; Mwanza has the highest number of squatter-settlements with unplanned hillside infrastructure and unplanned fish markets. Shinyanga is a mining region with widespread open defecation practices in the popular weekly community food markets. The scale of this yearâ€™s heavy rainfall, the resultant overflow of latrine facilities and poor hygiene practices in the affected communities have made this epidemic spread much faster than the countryâ€™s coping mechanism could contain it.
results.name: TZA: Epidemic - 01-2024 - TANZANIA CHOLERA OUTBREAK

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 04-2024 - Tanzania Rufiji flood
field_reports.description:
The ongoing heavy rainfall in the Rufiji District of the Coast Region has caused widespread devastation, leaving more than 88,000 individuals in dire need of essential services, including shelter, food, Wash intervention, healthcare and protection.Â 

This was said yesterday by Rufiji District Commissioner, Major Edward Gowele during Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) Vice Chairman, Abdulrahman Kinanaâ€™s special visit to console the flood victims.

He said that out of the 13 wards in Rufiji, 12 have been affected by the floods. Assessments have revealed that 23,000 households have been affected, with a total of 88,000 individuals in need of essential services such as shelter, food, WASH services, Security, protection and healthcare.

â€œIn addition to homes being submerged by the floods, approximately 33,930.24 hectares of crops have been affected,â€ Major Gowele stated.

He also mentioned that two people, a 20-year-old woman and a one-year-old child, have lost their lives due to the floods.

â€œWe have relocated the affected citizens to classrooms, but unfortunately, we have had to close some schools. For students currently in exam classes, we are arranging their transfer to neighbouring district schools,â€ he explained.

Major Gowele further noted that Mohoro Primary School, which was serving as a shelter for citizens, has also been surrounded by floodwaters.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Landslide - 12-2023 - Land slide and floods
field_reports.description: Tanzania has been experiencing enhanced rains since the end of October, with alarming level rainfall as a result of El Nino conditions and a positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) which are currently present in Pacic Ocean and Indian Ocean respectively. The Tanzania Meteorological Agency (TMA) indicate the rains are expected to peak in October but may continue into January 2024. From beginning of December, the first region to experience signicant and widespread oods was Manyara. Total number of households affected is 11000 (55,000 people) of which 5,500 households (27,500 people) are displaced. It's reported that there are 53 deaths, as a result of the heavy rains that fell at night on 2th December 2023, they have caused serious damage in the presence of floods, the eruption of the Volcano from Mount Hanang and the spread of heavy mud that led to the destruction of infrastructure, deaths and injuries in the district of Hanang, Manyara region, Tanzania

results.summary:
Torrential rains that began in mid-November have been bringing severe flooding to Tanzania causing numerous fatalities and destruction of infrastructure in Dar Es Salaam, Kigoma, Kagera, Geita and Unguja. Overall, initial estimates suggest that overÂ 75,000 people are directly affectedÂ and in need of urgent assistance. The Tanzania Meteorological Agency estimates that overÂ 6 million people have suffered some form of impact from the heavy rains and weather models now indicate that the there is more rain due over at least in the next five days. On 3 December alone, torrential rains caused massive landslides near Mount Hanang, Manyara region, in northern Tanzania. The floods swept away houses, roads and bridges, killing at least 68 people and injuring 116. Thousands of families have lost their homes and are sheltering in public buildings and with host families. Thus far homes belonging to at least 1,150 households (5,600 people) have been damaged, with 750 acres of farmland inundated.

The damage and loss of life are expected to increase as the true extent of the disaster is understood and as more areas are accessed by search and rescue teams. Rescue operations are underway with the help of the military as people are feared buried in thick mud, and the extent of mudslides has made retrieval of bodies and delivery of aid very challenging. Road access is limited, thus air transport is being used. Telecommunication has also been disrupted. Livelihoods have been severely affected, as most of the population depends on agriculture and livestock. This heightens the risk of increased food insecurity, in a country that has seen a spike in food insecurity and malnutrition in 2023 (over 60% increase).

Response: Tanzania Red Cross Society (TRCS) has sent disaster teams and 300 volunteers from the Manyara regional branch and surrounding branches to the affected areas to aid in search and rescue and first-aid, supporting those displaced with essential household items, food, water and sanitation. However, stocks are limited and much more support is needed. The Government has requested TRCS to scale up their support, and they are closely coordinating with the Department of Disaster Management within the Office of the Prime Minister.Â
results.name: TZA: 2023 Floods and Landslides

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 11-2023 - ZANZIBAR FLOOD
field_reports.description: Due to the information from the Tanzania meteorological authority (TMA), it predicted the presence of heavy rains at Unguja Mjini magharibi region exceeding the average starting on November 3 and continuing for four days in a row. Since the third day, there has been a lot of rain that has caused many water around people's residences and led to floods and houses sourrounded by many water. People became homeless, which led to asking for help from neighbors and going to emergency government houses.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 2023-10 - EL NINO TANZANIA
field_reports.description: Tanzania Meteorological Agency (TMA) is informing the public about the current ongoing El Nino status in the Pacific Ocean and its likelihood to affect our country (Tanzania). The Agency is making close follow up on the weather updates and it forecasts its likelihood to occur is from October to December 2023. The consequences from the El-Nino will greatly depend on the extent and the duration that it will last. Additionally, the consequences also depends on the conditions and direction of other weather weather systems including wind direction and sea temperature in the Indian ocean. This is likely to affect significant amount of human settlements, properties, buildings, and infrastructure systems that are crucial for the daily livelihood and the country development.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Food Insecurity - 2023-04 - LINDI FOOD INSECURITY
field_reports.description: According to the Government of Tanzania, Nachingwea district in Lindi region has recently faced a significant challenge of elephants invansion into farmsland and subsequent distruction of crops. A total of 14 out of 36 wards have been affected, and more than 730 households have been affected as well. This situation has resulted into severe food insecurity and nutrition, posing the threats to the well-being of the local communities. This also exacerbarates the human-elephants conflicts. The government through the District Administrative Secretary of Nachingwea district has requested for the urgent assistance to the affected households for food so as to meet their daily dietary needs.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-04 - DAR ES SALAAM CHOLERA OUTBREAK
field_reports.description:
Tanzania is currently experiencing one of the worst cholera outbreaks in years. The first case was registered in Ilala district in the Dar es salaam  region on 20 April 2023. The Tanzania Ministry of Health declared the cholera outbreak on 24 April 2023 after the increase and spread of confirmed cases. The cholera outbreak, initially limited to the eastern part of the country, has now spread from Kivule wards to Ilala and Buguruni wards in Dar es salaam region. 
There is also spread to neighboring Zambia, Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe where outbreaks are being declared.

Tanzania Red Cross Society report that there is an urgent need to address the risk factors of the outbreak, such as the provision of safe drinking water, especially in the hotspot areas. Several displaced communities in areas that were affected in 2023 by the Floods Dar es salaam and Mtwara are still living in precarious hygienic conditions due to high rainfall still increasing and raining. The floods and associated malnutrition that has affected vast areas of Tanzania are making the communities, particularly children, more at risk of mortality due to the increased vulnerability caused by their poor nutritional status.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 - KYELA FLOODS
field_reports.description:
On the night 17 and 18 April 2023, the villages around the Kiwira, Mbaka and Lufilyo rivers at  Kyela District, Mbeya Region experienced severe floods as a result of heavy downpour from the ongoing monsoon rains. So far, this flood has affected a total of 3 wards, and 9 villages including; Lupaso, Kilwa, Buluma, Kabanga, Isaka, Ndwanga, Kisyosyo, Ntundumano and Lusungo. Approximately 945 households  and 4725 population have been misplaced after their houses being surrounded by water and 113 houses have been destroyed. addiitonally, number of assets have been destroyed, farms, livestock and infrastructures. More damage is anticipanted as it keeps on raining. This calls for immediate response from the government and the National Society.

The affected three wards host around 6000 households, that approximately 30,000 population. The main economic activity in these wards is agriculture,livestock keeping and Fishing. The cultivated crops are rice, maize, cassava, sweetpotatoes, groundnuts and Cocoa. Most of the agricultural areas washed away by floods. TRCS branch (Mbeya Red Cross regional team) aside of local authorities visited the affected villages on 18th April 2023 and issued initial assessment data to start guiding the first emergency assistance to the affected communities

TRCS branch (Mbeya Red Cross regional team) aside of local authorities visited the affected villages on 18th April 2023 and issued initial assessment data to start guiding the first emergency assistance to the affected communities
results.name: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 - KYELA FLOODS

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 - TANZANIA RUKWA FLOOD DISASTER
field_reports.description: According to the social media reports (Jamii Forum)and ITV on 12th April 2023 flood occured in Rukwa Region at Milepa Ward, Talanda Village,  that caused 7 deaths of people, including 6 chidren and 1 woman. The overflow of Talanda River has caused extensive flood water to the residential area that resulted to people dispacement, damage of houses and assets, infrastructure, crops and livestock, and public areas. The National Society local branch currently is assessing how to best support the most vulnerable households affected by the disaster in order to respond effectively to the entire situation.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 -  Mtwara
field_reports.description: On the night of 1st April 2023, the villages around the Ruvuma River experienced severe floods as a result of heavy downpours from the ongoing monsoon rains. So far, this flood has affected the village of Kivava, especially in the suburbs of Sokoni and Kivukuni, villages of Angazo, and Kilamboma, and making 1,400 people displaced, representing 395 households affected in the suburbs of the market and the port. These 1,400 displaced people have been moved to temporary shelters in primary schools that are elevated due to their houses being surrounded by water. In addition, about 60 houses have collapsed with more than 100 toilets having collapsed and fields having been destroyed by water. The road from the village of Angazo to the village of Kilambo has been damaged, thus causing a lack of transportation and communication between those areas. Kivava village is one of the 110 villages in the district council. This village has 4 neighborhoods which are sokoni, kivukoni, dinanji, and lilumbi, the number of residents in this village is 1,976 and there are 518 households. The main economic activity in the village is agriculture and food business. The cultivated crops are rice, sorghum, cassava, cashews, coconuts, and legumes. Most of the agricultural areas were washed away by floods. TRCS branch (Mtwara Red Cross regional team) aside from local authorities visited the affected villages on 5th April and issued initial assessment data to start guiding the first emergency assistance to the affected communities Page 3 / 20 through local actions. TRCS branch, further to this assessment provided first distributions and helped the local authorities in the initial food distribution.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The government of Tanzania through the ministry of health informed the public of some illness that there was an Marburg virus disease reported in Tanzania Kagera region. eight people exhibiting symptoms including fever, vomiting, bleeding in various body parts and kidney failure were recorded out of which 5 dead. 

As a result, the government has sent a rapid response team to the northwestern  Kagera region which bordered with Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi to investigate the "communicable disease". These measures done by government include contact tracing and isolating cases of contacts.
field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-03 - MARBURG VIRUS DISEASE
field_reports.description:
On 16 March 2023, the Minister of Health Ummy Mwalimu announced that 7 cases and 5 deaths from an unknown disease had been reported in the Kagera Region. Samples taken on 16 March 2023 were confirmed to be Marburg Virus Disease on 21 March 2023 and the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania officially declared an outbreak. This is the first Marburg Virus Disease outbreak reported in the country.Â 

As of 19 April 2023, there are 9 total cases: 8 are confirmed and 1 is probable. There have been 6 fatalities and 3 cases in treatment. In total, 212 contacts have been identified and only 3 remain in isolation on follow-up.

TRCS has been working alongside other partners to support the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania in their response to this outbreak. TRCS is directly supporting Risk Communications and Community Engagement (RCCE) and Community Based Surveillance, including at various points of entry both domestic and international. In conjunction with UNICEF, TRCS has also supported WASH activities. In addition to actively responding, TRCS is also building capacity throughout the Kagera Region via trainings and volunteer engagement.

results.summary:
On 16 March 2023, the Minister of Health Ummy Mwalimu announced that 7 cases and 5 deaths from an unknown disease had been reported in the Kagera Region. Samples taken on 16 March 2023 were confirmed to be Marburg Virus Disease on 21 March 2023 and the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania officially declared an outbreak. This is the first Marburg Virus Disease outbreak reported in the country.Â 

As of 19 April 2023, there are 9 total cases: 8 are confirmed and 1 is probable. There have been 6 fatalities and 3 cases in treatment. In total, 212 contacts have been identified and only 3 remain in isolation on follow-up.

TRCS has been working alongside other partners to support the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania in their response to this outbreak. TRCS is directly supporting Risk Communications and Community Engagement (RCCE) and Community Based Surveillance, including at various points of entry both domestic and international. In conjunction with UNICEF, TRCS has also supported WASH activities. In addition to actively responding, TRCS is also building capacity throughout the Kagera Region via trainings and volunteer engagement.

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-01 - measles outbreak
field_reports.description: According to the government report and request Mbimbwe District at Katavi region in Tanzania affected by measles at large area and more than 2800 cases confirmed and 15 death reported of children under 5 year and the number increases day after day. Per the World Health Organization (WHO) and The united States Center of Disease Control and prevention (CDC), there is a 79% increase in measles cases across the world.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

results.summary: The Ebola outbreak was reported in Uganda on 20th September 2022 in Mubende District 50 km from the Tanzanian boarder, putting Tanzania at risk of cross-border transmission. The two countries share many points of entry, with people conducting economic activities without any movement restrictions. MOH Tanzania has mapped 10 regions at risk, 5 directly bordering Uganda, (Kagera, Kigoma, Geita, Mwanza, and Mara).
results.name: TZA: Epidemic 2022-11 Tanzania-Anticipatory Actions EVD Outbreak

field_reports.summary: TZA: Flood - 2022-04 - Flood in Kyela district,
field_reports.description:
From 26th to 29th April,2020 heavy rainfall occurred in Kyela, Rungwe and Ileje districts in   Mbeya and Songwe region (southern highlands Tanzania) which overflow to the lake Nyasa through 50 villages of 15 wards of Kyela district, resulting to population displacements, Deaths and extensive damages to infrastructure (roads, bridges, houses, schools, other public and religious buildings), and crop fields. 
The rapid assessment conducted by TRCS with Kyela local government authority reported Five (5) death of peoples, five (5) people missing, 21 injuries more than 630 HH displaced,  approximately to 3,150 people hosted at 21 different evacuation sites including schools, churches, mosque,  and other government buildings. (Keifo primary and secondary schools, katumba songwe secondary, ndandalo primary, mbogela primary, bujonde primary, kajunjumele primary, kipande secondary, bukinga primary and malangali primary) and 5 temporally shelter (KKT mwaya, EFATHA, Morovian mwaya, Mikoroshini center, Bujonde community center, Matema center and Makwale center) with limited access to basic services. 
Farm crops (hectors) also washed away including  (300 maizes, 500 rice, 1000 Vegetable, 400 Cocoa tree, 200 bananas and 50 cassava), almost 436 houses partially damaged and 318 are completely destructed, water infrastructure collapsed (5 clean water wells) reported to be contaminated. Communication network destructed, 4 bridges broken and 3 roads were swept away. Others destructed social services include 12 churches, 4 mosques and 35 schools. 
Currently there is no any health related serious cases reported.

results.name: TZA: Flood - 2022-04 - Flood in Kyela district,

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

field_reports.summary: TZA: Epidemic - 2022-04 - CHOLERA OUTBREAK  WESTERN REGIONS OF TANZANIA #2 (2022-04-29)
field_reports.description:
On 23 April, 2022, the Ministry of Health received an official notification from Kigoma and Katavi Regional Medical Officers about the presence of cases of Cholera in Kelya ward in Uvinza District Council in Kigoma and Tanganyika District Councils in Katavi.  The affected Villages are Sibwesa, Kalya and Kashagulu and Tanganyika lake shore in Tanganyika DC. Up to 25 Aprili Uvinza DC had a cumulative cholera cases 50 with no death while in Tanganyika DC was 20 cases. All patients are admitted for case management. 

In order to control this outbreak the Ministry has requested immediate support for Medical and WASH equipmentâ€™s and supplies,  enhancing access to clean and safe water, mapping for proper sanitation, reactive oral cholera vaccination, contact tracing and strengthening community and facility based surveillance. 

Government in collaboration with other partners have establish a coordination team where the updates are frequently shared.

More cases are being reported from the families which have initially reported cases. this alert for request to strengthen community surveillance. 

Using community volunteers, IPC is being conducted to infected houses, and awareness raised at minimal stance. More interventions and critical actions are required to foster behavior change and  action the community based surveillance, including engagement of community structure in the awareness creation and activate feedback channels to respond to community queries.

field_reports.summary: CHOLERA OUTBREAK SOUTH WESTERN TANZANIA
field_reports.description:
Cholera outbreak has been reported in Nkasi district Rukwa region. Government and other partners have intervened and are active in the field supporting the district team in the case management . More than 86 cases have been reported until Friday 11, March 2022. 
The Ministry of Health sent a rapid response team to help the regional and district health management team respond to this outbreak.
 UNICEF has mobilized some resources and transported them to Rukwa already and we have been facilitated coordination at the national level with WHO.
Government has requested partner support in the case management, surveillance, RCCE, supplies and logistical support.

results.name: CHOLERA OUTBREAK SOUTH WESTERN OF TANZANIA

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

results.summary:
The Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA) projected the Climate Outlook for November 2021 â€“ April 2022 (NDJFMA) rainfall season. The outlook was prepared in consultation with stakeholders from various sectors who provided an actionable recommendation to address expected impacts. The climate systems and outlook for Msimu rains, cover the unimodal areas (western, central, south-western highlands, southern, southern coast, and southern parts of Morogoro region) for the months of November 2021 â€“ April 2022.

Â 

Since 14th January 2022, several media outlets have reported a high rate of animal death which has drawn attention to the humanitarian actors and government. ITV media - 20.00hrs news bulletin, 14/01/2022, reported that more than 62,000 animals have died as a result of the drought, "Livestock is a bank of pastoralist communities now that it is dying of drought it becomes a problem and has affected their livelihood. As of 18 January 2022, TRCS has received calls from local government councilors (see picture 1 below) requesting immediate support referring to the Global Framework for Climate Services (GFCS) support conducted in Kiteto district two years ago
results.name: Tanzania - Food Insecurity

field_reports.summary: TANZANIA - TROPICAL CYCLONE JOBO - 21 (2021 - 04 - 21)
field_reports.description: Tropical cyclone, which is expected to make landfall in the Coast of Indian Ocean inTanzania on the 26th of April 2021. The cyclone currently has a maximum sustained wind speed of 83 Km/h and is expected to increase to 130km/h in the next 5 days https://www.gdacs.org/Cyclones/report.aspx?eventid=1000779&eventtype=TC. The expected region to be directly affected include Mtwara, Lindi, Dar es Salaam, zanzibar and Pwani. Even though the impacts are expected to escalate to other inland regions such as Morogoro, Dodoma, and Ruvuma. The cyclone is expected to cause high swells between 6m and 8m, rough sea conditions, heavy rain fall (400- 500mm), strong winds and flooding. Increase of rain is expected in Dar es Salaam, Tanga, Pemba, Lindi, Pwani, Morogoro, Mtwara regions and to the south coast of Tanzania and around Lake Victoria (UNOCHA update). Strong winds are expected along the coast and most at risk areas are in the central and south coast of Tanzania, Mtwara region (1,270,854 people), Dar es Salaam region (6,400,000 people), Pwani region (1, 265,000 people), Lindi region (864,652 people) and Zanzibar (1,580,000 people)

appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda
